executive_summary: The hose and belt manufacturing industry produces various products, including automotive V-belts, hydraulic hoses and belts for conveyors. Transportation, automotive and general industrial manufacturers, alongside oil, gas and food service industries, are extremely common buyers of hoses and belts. In general, the industry has exhibited solid post-pandemic growth. Rebounding industrial production, robust vehicle sales and recovering consumer markets have offset uncertainty and elevated interest rates, leading to steady growth. Overall, revenue has expanded at an expected CAGR of 0.7% to $6.7 billion through the current period, including a 0.4% increase in 2024, where profit reached 7.7%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Manufacturers Have Faced Severe Supply Chain Disruptions
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Hose and belt manufacturers have endured major supply chain uncertainty following the pandemic and the Russian invasion of Ukraine. In general, higher crude oil prices have translated into more expensive plastic and rubber inputs. Even so, leading manufacturers have leveraged extensive supply chain connections, globalization efforts and strong reputations to limit costs and pass higher prices relatively seamlessly onto buyers. Also, rubber prices have declined following 2021, enabling companies to cut prices. This practice has led to a wider range of available buyers, leading to strong post-pandemic profit growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Companies Have Dealt With Increasing Foreign Pressure
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Foreign manufacturers have leveraged lower wage, compliance, input and production costs to undercut domestic manufacturers and overwhelm many generic hose and belt markets. This trend has forced domestic manufacturers to pivot toward more niche markets that favor custom-built solutions. These markets more heavily prioritize quality, longevity and customization with less emphasis on price. These markets generally face less pressure from foreign competitors, leading to more stable growth. Even so, the dollar's appreciation poses a major threat to domestic markets. Imports have grown even less expensive, causing import penetration to eclipse 55.0%

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The pandemic and climbing inflation have limited growth opportunities in many key markets through the current period. In particular, economic uncertainty has diminished demand for new vehicles and machinery, cutting into demand for first-fit hoses and belts. Instead, weak conditions have led to more repairs, supporting demand for replacements from power transmission and fluid power markets. Even so, most markets display highly cyclical repair and replacement cycles; this trend leads to largely stable growth, aside from the pandemic.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: STRONGER INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION WILL SUPPORT HOSE AND BELT MANUFACTURERS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industrial production index will climb through the outlook period, signaling strong, stable growth in key manufacturing, mining and utilities markets. Hose and belt manufacturers will enjoy higher replacement and repair rates as industrial capacity rises to pre-pandemic levels. Amplified consumer confidence will also spur spending on other expensive durable goods, like appliances, prompting the industrial sector to purchase more hoses and belts to meet demand. This expected increase in industrial production will boost product demand, contributing to rising revenue during the outlook period.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: CUSTOMIZATION WILL PLAY A MAJOR ROLE
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Continued import penetration and increased specialization among buyers will encourage hose and belt manufacturers to embrace customized and specialized orders. Buyers will need increasingly specialized solutions to meet unique performance criteria. Hose and belt manufacturers will increasingly collaborate with customers to develop tailored solutions, fostering a more interactive and dynamic development process that aligns more closely with client needs.

Advances in material science are enabling the creation of stronger, lighter, and more durable products, broadening the scope of potential applications and enhancing product longevity. New manufacturing techniques, including 3D printing, will also enable rapid prototyping and the production of bespoke designs, reducing lead times and facilitating innovation. New manufacturing techniques, like 3D printing or computer-aided design (CAD), will also enable faster production and testing. These improvements also create opportunities for more complex and intricate designs that were previously impractical or impossible to achieve.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry manufacture a range of plastic and rubber hoses and belts, including garden hoses. These products are then sold to manufacturers; coal, oil and gas industries; and the automotive manufacturing market. The industry includes the manufacturing of plastic tubing, rubber tubing and fluid power hose assemblies.

threats: Price of plastic materials and resin

key_trends: Manufacturers compete on price, quality and performance.
Manufacturers that produce high-quality products can create successful market niches, even as producers face increased pressure from low-cost imports.
Manufacturers encounter significant pressure from imports
Leading manufacturers have developed strong reputations and dominant positions in key markets
Domestic hose and belt manufacturers have faced pressure from foreign manufacturers
Economic instability has limited growth opportunities for hose and belt manufacturers
Leading hose and belt manufacturers seek to expand operations to increase manufacturing capabilities
Large manufacturers often secure long-term contracts with key buyers and suppliers
Manufacturers must comply with regulations regarding the working pressure of hoses
Hose and belt manufacturers receive assistance through tariffs

market_segmentation.segment_description: Power transmission replacements make up the largest market for manufacturers. Power transmission products are critical inputs for stationary drives, mobile drives, engine systems, personal mobility and vertical lift platforms. This market is highly profitable and demand is stable as hoses and belts have set life cycles.

Fluid power replacements are essential to customers' operations and follow a natural maintenance cycle where hoses must be replaced every year or two to ensure the safety of operators as pressure-bearing hoses weaken and leak over time. Well-established distribution channels are in place to fulfill demand for replacement hoses.

First-fit power transmission buyers are the second-largest market for hose and belt manufacturers. Manufacturers of stationary drives, mobile drives, engine systems, personal mobility and vertical lift platforms use first-fit power transmissions. Demand for first-fit power transmissions has lagged as new vehicle sales decline.

First-fit fluid power makes up the smallest market segment for the industry. Buyers use fluid power products in hydraulic power systems to transfer pressurized liquid. Buyers also use fluid products in stationary hydraulics, mobile hydraulics, engine systems and other industrial applications. This market has rebounded alongside industrial production following the pandemic.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The industrial production index (IPI) measures output from the mining, manufacturing, electric and gas industries, which are major consumers of industrial hoses and belts. In general, demand mirrors industrial output. Growth in the industrial production index presents new opportunities for hose and belt manufacturers.

international_trade_points.trade_title: MOST IMPORTS COME FROM LOW-COST REGIONS
international_trade_points.trade_description: Most imports come from low-cost regions. China and Mexico account for more than 40.0% of total hose and belt imports. Manufacturers in these countries have taken advantage of lower wage, production and compliance costs to undercut domestic manufacturers.

international_trade_points.trade_title: MANUFACTURERS HAVE FACED MOUNTING IMPORT PENETRATION
international_trade_points.trade_description: Manufacturers have faced mounting import penetration. Import penetration has largely increased through the current period; increased pressure from low-cost importers, the dollar's appreciation and supply chain disruptions surrounding the pandemic have enabled import growth.

Favorable trade deals encourage exports. Mexico and Canada remain the largest export markets of industry products because of their proximity to the United States and favorable trade conditions like the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The US Dollar's Growth Hinders Exports
international_trade_points.trade_description: The dollar's growth has weakened export growth. As the TWI strengthens, domestic hoses and belts grow more expensive in international markets, causing foreign buyers to choose alternatives. In general, US-produced hoses and belts become less competitive in foreign markets as the dollar appreciates.

business_locations.location_description: In general, Canada and Mexico make up more than 50.0% of total exports. Mexico's burgeoning manufacturing and automotive sector has created robust demand for hoses and belts.

The Southeast serves as a hub for automotive, aerospace and industrial machinery manufacturing sectors, all of which heavily rely on hoses and belts. Being close to these key industries reduces shipping costs and delivery times. The region also offers more affordable real estate and lower labor costs compared to other parts of the United States, making it financially attractive for manufacturers to set up operations.

The Great Lakes region accounts for the second-largest concentration of establishments. Proximity to major automotive manufacturers, particularly in Michigan and Ohio, creates steady demand for hoses and belts. The Great Lakes' extensive network of highways, railroads, and navigable waterways enables efficient transportation of raw materials and finished products, reducing logistical costs for manufacturers.

The West, particularly California, is home to a vast network of tech companies and R&D facilities. Hose and belt manufacturers benefit from close proximity to cutting-edge manufacturers. The West Coast's ports facilitate easy access to international markets in Asia and beyond. This strategic location helps manufacturers streamline their export processes and expand their global footprint.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Manufacturers must mark hoses with the rated maximum working pressure of the hose. Maximum working pressures are typically based upon a ratio of burst pressure to working pressure. Higher ratio products are more expensive to produce because of the excess bulk required.

regulations_points.regulation_title: OSHA (OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH ADMINISTRATION) REGULATIONS
regulations_points.regulation_description: OSHA ensures workplace safety through regulations that manufacturers must adhere to while producing hoses and belts. This includes guidelines for handling materials, operating machinery, and protecting employees from hazardous substances.

ASTM International develops technical standards for materials, products and services, ensuring quality and safety. These regulations include specifications for material properties, performance requirements and testing methods.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is mature, increasing barriers to entry.
High and increasing globalization level increases barriers.

basis_points.basis_description: Manufacturers compete on price, quality and performance.
Manufacturers that produce high-quality products can create successful market niches.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Large manufacturers benefit from economies of scale
concentration_points.concentration_description: While most establishments are small, the industry does have some large companies that benefit from economies of scale.
Smaller manufacturers and entrants have struggled to generate stable revenue and acquire new contracts.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Companies Have Dealt With Volatile Purchasing Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Hose and belt manufacturers have endured significant input price volatility following the pandemic and the Russian invasion of Ukraine. In particular, surging crude oil prices have contributed to elevated prices for chemicals, petroleum-based polymers, rubber and plastic resins.

In general, natural materials are more expensive; many companies have emphasized more sustainable manufacturing processes, contributing to higher purchasing costs. Leading manufacturers have also leveraged long-term contracts and supply chain globalization to mitigate input price volatility.

Skilled labor is an essential aspect of hose and belt manufacturing. Companies primarily rely on experienced employees for research, development, design and quality control roles, though most manufacturers have automated low-wage positions.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Hose and belt manufacturing is capital and labor-intensive. Sourcing skilled labor and investing in state-of-the-art equipment requires substantial resources, creating a steep entry barrier for smaller or less-funded ventures.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Hoses and belts have predictable maintenance cycles, making it easier for manufacturers and buyers to plan out replacement purchases. This practice generates stable demand for the industry.

Hose and belt manufacturers have faced severe supply chain disruptions following the pandemic and the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Higher crude oil prices rippled through supply chains, leading to elevated rubber and plastic prices.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Manufacturers depend on US manufacturing activity and emerging market demand
volatility_points.volatility_description: Sales of industry-related belts and hoses rely on US manufacturing activity, especially automotive, truck, construction and agricultural machinery manufacturing, in addition to downstream demand from oil and gas exploration (E&P).

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: MANUFACTURERS SEEK TO IMPROVE PRODUCT CHARACTERISTICS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Advances in barrier technology have enabled manufacturers to coat the inside of hose products with a material that is resistant to fluids. These materials form a barrier between the fluid and the hose casing, reducing permeation over time.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: MANUFACTURERS COMBINE MATERIALS TO IMPROVE PRODUCT LIFE
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Over time, belts under high tension face heavy stretch and wear. Belt technologies have combined rubber with other fibers to reduce stretching in belts. Manufacturers have combined rubber and other fibers to produce higher-quality products.

FAQs.question: Have exports offered an opportunity for your company?
FAQs.answer: Exports fluctuate in response to currency fluctuations. When the American dollar depreciates, manufacturers are better positioned to find markets for their products abroad.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Sales for manufacturers in this industry are particularly influenced by trends in US industrial production and oil and gas exploration.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing heavily in R&D to meet changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers in this industry gain a competitive edge if they are able to develop more durable hoses and belts. Manufacturers have been investing heavily in R&D to create high-quality products to compete with low-cost alternatives.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers are directly affected by the price of rubber. Rubber is not grown domestically because the climate is not conducive to the cultivation of rubber trees. Manufacturers can mitigate price volatility by maintaining strong relationships with upstream suppliers.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to safeguard your company's proprietary information?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry routinely file patents for new products or product improvements. Companies are also increasingly investing in safeguarding against cyber attacks and bolstering their information security.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers have been trying to contain wage costs through automation, which has lowered the number of employees. Moving forward, companies will likely continue to pursue automation in order to reduce their labor costs.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to comply with new environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Improving product standards to meet downstream customers environmental compliance needs, especially tubes and hoses that would transport hazardous materials, is high priority for companies in this industry.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers are required to label their hoses with the rated maximum working pressure of the hose. Companies in this industry are also required to comply with hygienic and social distancing requirements to curb the spread of the coronavirus pandemic.

FAQs.question: How often does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: When manufacturers need to make capital expenditures it is typically costly. Equipment used in the production of rubber is replaced on a cycle of every 10-20 years, on average.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Comparison between manufacturers in the industry and their competitors depends on the products they manufacture, the size of their operations and <UNKNOWN>

FAQs.question: Input prices for raw materials
FAQs.answer: Input prices for raw materials like plastics and resins influence the profit of miscellaneous plastic product manufacturers, the industry's main competitor in downstream construction and manufacturing markets.
